contextId.information: Here being on the "throne" refers to ruling over a kingdom. AT: "makes new kings rule over their kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: places kings on their thrones

contextId.information: The place is used to represent the people who live there. AT: "the people of the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the place where the human beings live

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men made and set up a statue by his command is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar had made and set up a statue. AT: "Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to make a gold statue ... They set it up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Nebuchadnezzar made a gold statue ... He set it up

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men had set up the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar had set it up. AT: "the statue that Nebuchadnezzar's men had set up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the statue that Nebuchadnezzar had set up

contextId.information: Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. AT: "people from different nations and who speak different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.information: Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who spoke different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men had set up the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar had set it up. AT: "the golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar's men had set up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the golden statue that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men have set up the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar has set it up. AT: "the golden statue your men have set up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the golden statue you have set up

contextId.information: Here "mind" refers to deciding. To "make up your mind" is an idiom that means to firmly decide. AT: "Have you firmly decided" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Have you made your minds up

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men have set up the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar has set it up. AT: "the golden statue that my men have set up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the golden statue that I have set up

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men have made the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar has made it. AT: "the statue that my men have made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the statue that I have made

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to power to punish. AT: "from your punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of your hand

contextId.information: That Nebuchadnezzar's men set up the statue is spoken of as if Nebuchadnezzar set it up. AT: "the golden statue your men set up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the golden statue you set up

contextId.information: Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who speak different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.information: This phrase is using the name Nebuchadnezzar to refer to the king's army. AT: "the army of Nebuchadnezzar his father had taken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Nebuchadnezzar his father had taken

contextId.information: Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who speak different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.information: This phrase does not mean King Nebuchadnezzar put people to death himself, but rather those he commanded. AT: "Nebuchadnezzar commanded his soldiers to kill those he wanted to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He put to death those he wanted to die

contextId.information: Here "breath" refers to life and "hand" refers to power or control. AT: "God who gives you breath" or "God who has control over your entire life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: God who holds your breath in his hand

contextId.information: Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who spoke different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.information: Translators may write a footnote like this: "Horns are a symbol of power and represent powerful leaders." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the horns

contextId.information: Here "his hand" refers to his control. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The newest king will control the religous festivals and laws" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: These things will be given into his hand

contextId.information: Rams do not have hands. Here "hand" refers to the ram's power. AT: "to rescue anyone from him" or "to rescue anyone from his power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to rescue anyone out of his hand

contextId.information: Here "he" refers to his power. AT: "his rule will end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will be broken

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to power. This can be also stated in positive form. AT: "not by any human power" or "by divine power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: not by any human hand

contextId.information: Here "face" represents Daniel's attention. AT: "I focused my attention on the Lord God" or "I directed my thoughts toward the Lord God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I turned my face to the Lord God

contextId.information: Here "name" refers to God's authority. AT: "spoke with your authority" or "spoke as your representative" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: spoke in your name

contextId.information: Here "voice" refers to the things that Yahweh commanded. AT: "we have not done what he told us to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: we have not obeyed his voice

contextId.information: Here "mighty hand" is a metonym for strength. AT: "with great strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with a mighty hand

contextId.information: Here falling represents dying in battle. AT: "will have his army kill many thousands of his enemies" or "will kill many thousands of his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will make tens of thousands to fall

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents the mind or thoughts of a person. The idiom "his heart set against" means to be determined to oppose something. This can be stated as a new sentence. AT: "riches. He will be determined to oppose the holy covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: riches, with his heart set against the holy covenant

contextId.information: The ships represent the army coming in those ships. AT: "an army will come from Kittim in ships in order to fight his army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: ships of Kittim will come against him

contextId.information: Here "know" means "be faithful." AT: "who are faithful to their God"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who know their God

contextId.information: This refers to the hill in Jerusalem where God's temple was. See how you translated somewhat similar phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:09:15|9:16]] and [[:en:bible:notes:dan:09:20|9:20]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the mountain of the beauty of holiness

contextId.information: Here "words" represents the book. AT: "close this book and keep it sealed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: close up these words; keep the book sealed
